proposals.reasoning: This matches the broad table consensus for a low-controversy, low-noise start. Keeping the proposer (me) off Mission 1 avoids auto-clearing myself too early and gives us a cleaner read: if this mission fails, we immediately know at least one of Bob or Diana is evil; if it succeeds, we can tentatively trust both and build from there.

votes.comment: This is a broadly agreed, low-drama opening team and rejecting it without cause would look more suspicious than useful right now.
I know I’m good and there’s strong table consensus on this low-info, low-drama start; fine using Mission 1 to test me+Diana.
Standard low-risk Mission 1 team with broad consensus and no red flags; good for early info.
Standard low-info M1 with broad consensus and a clean read; no reason as good to overcomplicate the opener.
Solid low-info start that matches table consensus; happy to get a clean baseline read from Bob–Diana before pushing for more complex teams.
Solid low-info opener without known evil Alice; good either for a clean pass or a tight suspect pair if it fails.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d rather start simple with two people who seem pretty reasonable so far—something like Bob plus one of Charlie/Diana, and I’m also fine going myself if people want fresh info on me early.
I like me plus one of Charlie or Diana to start; I’d rather leave you off Mission 1, Alice, just so we’re not letting the proposer auto-include themselves right away.
I’m good with keeping it simple here—Bob plus one of Charlie/Diana feels like a solid low-risk start, and I slightly prefer Bob–Diana just so we’re not overindexing on the loudest early voices.
I’m fine with the Bob–Diana idea or Bob–Charlie; keeping Alice off this first one makes sense so we’re not just auto-trusting the proposer before we’ve seen any mission results.
Bob plus Diana sounds fine to me for Mission 1—low drama, low risk—and I’m okay staying off the first team so we get a cleaner read on the result.

Bob–Diana feels like a solid, low-controversy starting point, and I’d rather not include the proposer (Alice) on Mission 1 when we don’t have any info yet. Let’s take the clean read here and worry about mixing lineups on Mission 2 once we see how this goes.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Bob and Diana was clean, so keeping that core is the most information-preserving play. Adding Frank aligns with both Charlie’s, Diana’s, and Frank’s stated preferences and introduces only one new variable instead of reshuffling the entire team or prematurely re-adding Alice. This gives us a high chance of success if the M1 core is good, while generating clear info: a fail here points strongly at Frank (or, less likely, a hidden evil in the M1 core), whereas a success solidifies Bob+Diana as a trusted base for future missions.

votes.comment: Too early to lock in a strong-looking Bob+Diana+Frank core after just one clean 2-person mission; I’d rather see either Alice or Charlie included before we anoint a trusted block.
Keeps the clean M1 core (me+Diana) and adds just one new variable (Frank), which is both info-rich and likely safe given current data.
Keeps the clean Bob+Diana core and adds just one new player (Frank), which matches my stated preference and gives good info with reasonable risk.

Keeps the clean M1 core of Bob+me and adds just one new variable in Frank, which matches my stated preference and gives strong info while still being likely good if M1 was clean for the right reasons.
I still prefer rerunning Alice with the proven Bob+Diana core over introducing Frank as a new unknown here; this team doesn’t give me the clearest info if it fails.
Keeps the clean M1 core and adds just one new player, which is solid info-gathering and reasonably safe.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’d really like to keep Bob and Diana together as a core; I’m fine adding either myself or someone who hasn’t gone yet so we can start getting more info without breaking what’s worked.

I like keeping me and Diana together for now, but a 2‑person clean isn’t proof of anything yet, so I’d lean toward adding someone new (maybe Charlie or Frank) over just defaulting to Alice again for better info.
I’m good keeping the Bob + Diana core after a clean start, and I’d lean toward adding Frank this time so we get new info without piling the same three people together too early.
I definitely want to keep Bob and me together after the clean M1, and I slightly prefer adding Frank over re‑running Alice so we get fresh info without overcommitting to the same trio this early.

Keeping Bob + Diana together makes sense after a clean start, but I’d slightly rather add Alice than double‑dip into new people right away—if we throw in both a new third and break the M1 trio immediately, it’ll be harder to read where a fail comes from.

I’m on board with keeping Bob + Diana together after a clean start, and I’d slightly prefer adding me over re‑running Alice so we get fresh info without just locking in the same trio. If people are unsure about that, I’d still rather see a new third (me or Charlie) than default back to Alice this early.

proposals.reasoning: We should lock in the proven Bob/Diana/Frank core after two clean missions and add exactly one new player. Between the remaining options, adding Charlie gives us a fresh test while avoiding the risk of auto‑confirming Alice, who has been central but not yet directly tested on a mission. This team maximizes our use of known-good results, limits the introduction of potential evil to a single new slot, and preserves the strongest informational backbone we have so far.

votes.comment: I still think we should be testing me with the proven Bob/Diana/Frank core; swapping in Charlie instead gives us less information on the most central unresolved slot.

The Bob/Diana/Frank core is very likely clean after two successes; adding only Charlie aligns with Frank’s preference and avoids auto-clearing Alice, who feels more likely to be evil than Charlie or Eve right now.
Bob/Diana/Frank as a core have two clean missions; adding myself as the only new variable keeps a highly trusted backbone while minimally expanding risk.

We should keep the proven Bob/Diana/Frank core; adding exactly one new player (Charlie) is a reasonable, low-variance test that preserves our strongest info and still gives us a good shot at a clean third success.
I still prefer adding Alice over Charlie to the proven Bob/Diana/Frank core so we get direct info on the player who’s been most central; this feels like a side-step around that check.
Keeps the proven Bob/Diana/Frank core and adds a single new player in Charlie, which is the safest way to test someone new without disrupting what’s been working.

discussion.content: I really think we should keep the proven core of Bob/Diana/Frank and just add one new person—I'd like to be on this one so we get some info on me instead of reshuffling a working group.

Sticking with Bob/Diana/Frank feels mandatory now—two clean missions with that core is the best info we’ve got. For the 4th, I’m fine testing Alice here, but if people are uneasy we should talk through Charlie vs Eve before we lock it in.

Keeping Bob/Diana/Frank feels non‑negotiable after two clean runs, and between Alice/Charlie/Eve I slightly prefer adding Alice here so we get info on someone who’s been involved from the start. If people really hate that, I’d rather pivot to Charlie than start dragging Eve into the core this late.

I’m absolutely on board with locking in the Bob/Diana/Frank core again, and between the options I also slightly prefer adding Alice here so we get hard info on someone already central rather than suddenly bringing Eve into the mix. If people are really uncomfortable with Alice, I’d rather we pivot to Charlie than start rebuilding the team from scratch.

I’m fine sticking with the Bob/Diana/Frank core again, and between the options I’d also rather add Alice here—she’s been central from the start, so this gives us the clearest info without suddenly dragging a completely new face like me into a critical mission.

I definitely want to keep the Bob/Diana/Frank core, but I’d slightly rather add Charlie than Alice here so we’re not just auto‑locking in someone who hasn’t actually been on a mission yet. Getting a fresh read while preserving a proven trio feels like the safest way to avoid a surprise flip later.

evil_discussion.content: If I had to bet, I’d say Bob is Merlin: he was shaping every mission from the start, always “cautiously” trusting the right people and pushing really sound, low‑drama lineups that never seriously risked including too many evils. Diana feels more like a strong, agreeable townie riding the consensus with Bob, while Charlie and Frank’s small disagreements (especially Frank pushing Charlie over me on M3) look more like normal good‑logic wobble than someone secretly steering with extra info.

I’m mostly with Alice that Bob is the best Merlin candidate: he kept nudging “safe” structures (Bob+Diana core, then Bob/Diana/Frank) in ways that always ended up excluding us without looking like he was hard‑clearing anyone, and his language is very measured—“I like,” “I’d lean toward,” “if people are uneasy”—like he’s carefully steering, not driving. Diana reads more like a consensus‑hugger amplifying Bob’s takes, and Frank’s push for Charlie over Alice on M3 felt like genuine uncertainty rather than informed steering, so if it’s not Bob, my distant second pick would be Charlie as a quieter, slightly more theory‑driven Merlin.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Bob consistently shaped the mission structures from the start, carefully advocating for low-risk, low-drama lineups that always ended up excluding the known evil players while never appearing to hard-clear anyone. His cautious, hedged language (“I like,” “I’d lean toward,” “if people are uneasy”) reads like someone deliberately steering with extra information, whereas others (especially Diana) mostly echoed or followed those structures rather than originating them.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I blended in reasonably well on the early missions and didn’t create much suspicion, but I failed to generate enough doubt around Merlin’s identity, which made the assassination miss. Next time, I should push harder to create competing Merlin narratives (especially around Charlie and Bob) and be more proactive in shaping table talk instead of mostly riding along with the successful teams.

player_observations.Bob: Played very cleanly and quietly, accepting teams and results without drawing much attention, which made you look like generic good rather than a power role—this low-key style helped hide Merlin effectively.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, you seemed cautious but willing to back successful patterns, and you didn’t over-assert your information, which kept evil from locking onto you as a power role while still subtly guiding team choices.
player_observations.Diana: You came across as straightforward and trustworthy, consistently landing on correct teams without a lot of drama, which reinforced the narrative that the early success streak was just good players making solid reads.
player_observations.Eve: You stayed nicely under the radar as Mordred, but we didn’t manufacture enough visible disagreement or failed missions together, which made the board state too clean and ultimately made it easy for good to win.
player_observations.Frank: You played a very low-profile Merlin, guiding team selections just enough to keep missions clean while never sounding like you had strong hidden info, which made the final assassination guess drift away from you.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy and helped secure clean teams, which contributed to three straight successful missions and kept suspicion relatively low on me despite the assassin’s final guess. I could improve by being a bit more vocal about my reasoning and reads during team discussions to better guide the table without overstepping Merlin’s subtlety.

player_observations.Alice: Played confidently and leaned into appearing trustworthy, which made her early leadership seem reasonable despite being evil (Morgana). She blended well with the successful mission outcomes, suggesting she’s good at riding along with safe teams to maintain cover.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, Charlie seemed careful and methodical, not pushing too hard but supporting teams that ended up being correct. Their subtle support instead of loud directing suggests they prefer a measured, information-gathering style.
player_observations.Diana: Diana came across as reliably good, staying on successful teams without generating much suspicion. Her low-key style helped maintain team stability and trust throughout the missions.
player_observations.Eve: Eve stayed under the radar as Mordred, not drawing much direct heat even though evil lost. Their quiet presence suggests a more reserved evil style, relying on others (like Morgana) to take the visible risks.
player_observations.Frank: Frank balanced guiding the game and staying hidden very well as Merlin, consistently ending up on correct teams without looking overly informed. Their subtle influence on team composition clearly helped good win while still dodging the assassin’s final guess.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed vigilant about tracking potential Merlin signals and correctly kept Frank in my Merlin pool despite very clean mission results, which helped protect him from assassination. I could improve by more actively sowing doubt about non-Merlin strong-town reads (like Bob) so the assassin has a harder time narrowing down the real Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very clean Morgana game, blending in well with the early successful missions and not overreaching, which made her a credible power-role candidate. Her restraint in pushing narratives helped keep suspicion low on herself while creating plausible alternatives for Merlin.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as very naturally good-leaning, with consistent reasoning and team selections that fit the mission outcomes. His playstyle made him a strong, believable town core member and an understandable assassination target.
player_observations.Diana: Played a solid, low-drama good game: supported sensible teams and didn’t create unnecessary conflict, which made her seem reliably good without drawing much power-role attention. Her calm consistency helped stabilize team selection and reinforce confidence in the early mission successes.
player_observations.Eve: As Mordred, stayed impressively under the radar and didn’t trigger strong suspicion despite all missions passing. Her quiet, non-flashy style made it hard to pin her as evil, but it also limited her ability to steer the narrative or generate misreads on Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: Did an excellent job as Merlin of guiding teams subtly enough that all missions succeeded while not appearing overly controlling or omniscient. His measured tone and non-aggressive suggestions helped him look like just another solid good player rather than a clear power role, contributing directly to the failed assassination.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and built trust early by being on and supporting all three successful teams, which helped maintain a stable, low-conflict game for good. I could improve by being more vocal about my reasoning for trusting certain people (like Frank and Bob) so that evil has a harder time subtly steering suspicions and the assassin has less room to operate.

player_observations.Alice: Took an assertive early-leader role and blended in well despite being evil, using the clean first mission to appear reliably good and avoid drawing suspicion.
player_observations.Bob: Played very straightforwardly good, supporting successful teams and projecting a natural, non-defensive vibe that unfortunately made him a plausible Merlin target at the end.
player_observations.Charlie: Behaved like a cautious but engaged information role, aligning with good teams while not over-claiming insight, which fit Percival’s need to protect Merlin by staying somewhat opaque.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed under the radar and avoided noisy conflicts, which is strong for Mordred, but the lack of mission fails or decisive steering made it harder for evil to create real doubt.
player_observations.Frank: Balanced contributing to good team selection with not being too obviously insightful, guiding us onto three perfect teams while still looking like a solid but not screamingly-obvious Merlin.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed too cautious as Mordred, allowing all three missions to pass and giving Merlin very little pressure or ambiguity to work with, which made endgame reads easier for good. I should have coordinated a planned early fail with Alice to create at least one noisy mission and paid more attention to subtle behavioral clues from Frank that hinted at extra information.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very low-disruption Morgana, blending in as a solid, trustworthy proposer, which unfortunately made it harder for us to generate suspicion and chaos. Their restraint was good for staying hidden but didn’t create the classic Merlin/Morgana tension we needed.
player_observations.Bob: Maintained a consistently clean, straightforward good-player image, rarely overexplaining or forcing reads, which made him an easy but ultimately incorrect assassination target. His willingness to be on early successful teams without pushing hard for control felt very typical of relaxed good play.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, Charlie projected a cautious, somewhat probing presence, asking just enough questions to look engaged without painting a clear target on themselves. Their reads seemed deliberately conservative, which helped protect both Merlin and their own identity.
player_observations.Diana: Played in a very natural, low-flash manner, accepting teams and participating without drawing attention, which strongly contributed to a stable, low-conflict game state favoring good. Her lack of big, performative reads made her seem reliably good without ever looking like a power role.
player_observations.Frank: Frank’s behavior was subtly confident and aligned with good outcomes, especially in supporting teams that all ended up passing, which in hindsight looks like informed positioning from Merlin. He avoided loud, directive leadership and instead nudged things in a way that kept suspicion off himself while still guiding the table toward correct teams.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably hidden as Merlin while still nudging people toward trusting Bob and Diana and keeping missions clean, which helped secure three straight successes and avoid any FAIL cards. I could improve by more actively sowing doubt about Alice and Eve earlier without making my resistance to them look too pointed, as that might have further reduced the odds of the assassin targeting a core good player like Bob.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very convincing Morgana, leaning into early team proposals that looked safe and not overpushing any sabotage, which made her feel like a cautious but cooperative good player. Her subtlety and lack of overt agenda pressure helped keep suspicion off her despite being evil.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as straightforward and consistent, with decisions that matched a typical good-player risk profile and no noticeable over-defensiveness, which made it easier to trust him. His willingness to go on early teams without hedging or angling for complex logic supported the image of a genuinely good agent.
player_observations.Charlie: Behaved like a careful information-gatherer, asking questions and evaluating team compositions in a way that matched a typical Percival profile. He didn’t tunnel too hard on any single read, which helped keep both Merlin candidates (Alice and me) plausibly in play for much of the game.
player_observations.Diana: Played a low-drama, cooperative style that fit well with a solid, dependable good role, especially by accepting and performing on early teams without creating noise. Her lack of strong agenda-driving made her an easy inclusion for missions once early successes started to stack up.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively under the radar, which is often effective for Mordred, avoiding big, risky pushes that would draw attention to alignment. By not placing herself in key mission spots or debate focal points too aggressively, she made it harder for good to justify explicit suspicion without looking paranoid.
